sentences.sentence: “It can’t be a coincidence,” he cried, at last springing from his chair and pacing wildly up and down the room, “it is impossible that it should be a mere chance.
The very pills which I suspected( 怀疑 ), in the case of Drebber, are actually found after the death of Stangerson.
And yet they have no effect.
What can it mean? Surely my whole chain of reasoning cannot have been false.
It is impossible! And yet this dog is none the worse.
Ah, I have it! I have it!” With a perfect cry of delight he rushed to the box, cut the other pill in two, dissolved( 溶解 ) it, added milk, and presented it to the dog.
The unfortunate creature’s tongue seemed hardly to have tasted it before it gave a sudden shake in every part of its body, and lay as rigid and lifeless as if it had been struck by lightning.
Sherlock Holmes drew a long breath, and wiped the sweat from his forehead.
“I should have more faith,” he said, “I ought to know by this time that when a fact goes against what I know, there must be some other explanation.
Of the two pills in that box, one was of the most deadly poison, and the other was entirely harmless.
I ought to have known that before I saw the box at all.”
“All this seems strange to you,” continued Holmes, “because you failed at the beginning of the inquiry( 调查 ) to grasp the importance of the single real clue( 线索 ) which was presented to you.
I had the good fortune to take hold of that, and everything which has happened since then has served to confirm my original assumption.
Hence( 因此 ) things, which have confused you and made the case more mysterious( 神秘 ), have served to help me confirm my conclusions.
It is a mistake to confuse strangeness with mystery( 谜案 ).
The most usual crime is often the most mysterious( 神秘的 ) because it presents no new or special features( 特点 ) from which deductions( 推理 ) may be drawn.
This murder would have been more difficult to solve if the body of the victim had been simply found lying in the roadway.
These strange details( 细节 ), far from making the case more difficult, have really had the effect of making it less so.”
Mr. Gregson, who had listened to this talk with considerable impatience( 不耐烦 ), could be silent no longer.
“Look here, Mr. Sherlock Holmes,” he said, “we are all ready to acknowledge that you are a smart man, and that you have your own methods of working.
But we want something more than mere theory and teaching now.
It is a case of catching the man.
I thought I had solved the case, but it seems I was wrong.
Young Charpentier could not have been involved in this second affair.
Lestrade went after his man, Stangerson, and it appears that he was wrong too.
You have thrown out hints( 提示 ) here, and hints( 提示 ) there, and seem to know more than we do,
but the time has come when we feel that we have a right to ask you to tell us clearly how much you do know of the business.
Can you name the man who did it?”
“I cannot help feeling that Gregson is right, sir,” remarked Lestrade.
“We have both tried, and we have both failed.
You have remarked more than once since I have been in the room that you had all the evidence which you require.
Surely you will not hold it back any longer.”
“Any delay in arresting the murderer,” I said, “might give him time to commit some fresh murders.”
“There will be no more murders,” Holmes said at last.
“You can forget about that idea.
You have asked me if I know the name of the murderer.
I do. However, the mere knowing of his name is a small thing compared with the power of laying our hands upon him.
This I expect very shortly to do.
I have good hopes of managing it through my own arrangements.
But it is a thing which needs delicate handling, for we have a desperate man to deal with.
The murderer is supported, as I have had occasion to prove, by another who is as clever as himself.
As long as this man has no idea that anyone has a clue( 线索 ), there is some chance of arresting him.
But if he had the slightest suspicion( 疑心 ), he would change his name, and disappear in an instant among the four million people of this great city.

Without meaning to hurt either of your feelings, I am bound to say that I consider these men to be too intelligent and capable( 有本领 ) for the official force to handle, and that is why I have not asked your assistance.
If I fail I will, of course, take all the blame due to my mistake.
At present I am ready to promise that the moment that I can speak with you without risking my own plans, I will do so.”
No one else had time to speak before there was a tap at the door, and the spokesman of the street Arabs, young Wiggins, came into the house.
“Please, sir,” he said, “I have the cab downstairs.”
“Good boy,” said Holmes. “Why don’t you introduce these handcuffs( 手铐 ) at Scotland Yard?” he continued, taking a pair of steel handcuffs( 手铐 ) from a drawer.
“See how beautifully the spring( 弹簧 ) works. They fasten in a second.”
“The old handcuffs( 手铐 ) are good enough,” remarked Lestrade,
“if we can only find the man to put them on.”
“Very good, very good,” said Holmes, smiling.
“The cabman( 马车夫 ) may as well help me with my boxes. Just ask him to come up, Wiggins.”
Holmes was busily packing his things when the cabman( 马车夫 ) entered the room.
“Just give me a help with this buckle( 扣子 ), cabman( 马车夫 ),” he said, kneeling( 跪着 ) over his task, and never turning his head.
The fellow came forward and put down his hands to help.
At that moment there was a sharp sound of metal, and Sherlock Holmes sprang to his feet again.
“Gentlemen,” he cried, with flashing eyes, “let me introduce you to Mr. Jefferson Hope, the murderer of Enoch Drebber and of Joseph Stangerson.”
The whole thing occurred in a moment—so quickly that I had no time to realize it.

I still remember that instant—Holmes’ triumphant( 得意的 ) expression, and the cabman( 马车夫 )’s dazed( 茫然的 ), savage face as he glared at the glittering( 闪闪发光的 ) handcuffs( 手铐 ) which had appeared as if by magic upon his wrists.
Then, with a roar( 吼叫 ) of fury( 狂怒 ), the prisoner freed himself from Holmes’ grasp, and threw himself through the window.
Wood and glass gave way before him.
But before he got quite through, Gregson, Lestrade, and Holmes sprang upon him like so many dogs.
He was dragged back into the room, and then started a great conflict.
He was so powerful and so fierce that the four of us were shaken off again and again.
It was not until Lestrade succeeded in getting the man’s hand inside his scarf and choked him that we made him realize that his struggles were of no use.
Even then we felt no security until we had tied his feet as well as his hands.
Then we rose to our feet out of breath.
“We have his cab,” said Sherlock Holmes. “It will be useful to take him to Scotland Yard.
And now, gentlemen,” he continued, with a pleasant smile, “we have reached the end of our little mystery( 谜题 ).
You are very welcome to put any questions that you like to me now, and there is no danger that I will refuse to answer them.”

question.cn: 根据Holmes的猜想，会有新的谋杀案发生吗？
question.en: According to Holmes’s assumption, would there be any more murders?

options.cn: 是的，会有新的谋杀案发生。
options.en: Yes, there would be more murders.

options.cn: 不，不会再有新的谋杀案。
options.en: No, there would not be more murders.

analysis: 文中描述两位侦探都希望Holmes能告知他们凶手的身份，以防会有新的谋杀案发生，Holmes却表示“There will be no more murders...You can forget about that idea.” 说明凶手不会再作案了，故选B项。

question.cn: 是谁将马车夫带到Holmes的公寓的？
question.en: Who brought the cabman to Holmes’s apartment?

analysis: 文中描述 “‘No one else had time to speak before there was a tap at the door, and the spokesman of the street Arabs, young Wiggins, came into the house.‘Please, sir,’ he said, ‘I have the cab downstairs.’”说明是Holmes组织的流浪小孩队伍的成员将马车夫带到Holmes公寓楼下，故选A项。
通过今天的故事，当Holmes抓住马车夫时，向在场的所有人说“let me introduce you to Mr. Jefferson Hope, the murderer of Enoch Drebber and of Joseph Stangerson.” 说明这位马车夫就是凶手，故选B项。

question.cn: 凶手被认出来后有着怎样的反应？
question.en: What was the murderer’s reaction after he was recognized?

options.en: He confessed the crime right away .
He said that he was innocent.

options.cn: 他尝试着逃跑但是失败了。
options.en: He tried to escape but failed.

analysis: 文中描述凶手在知道罪行败露后“Then, with a roar of fury, the prisoner freed himself from Holmes’ grasp, and threw himself through the window” 并且后面与侦探们发了激烈的冲突，说明凶手是想逃跑，但最终失败。故选C项。

question.cn: 从今天的故事中，我们可以得知关于药片的哪些信息？
question.en: What can we learn about the pills from today’s story?

options.cn: 一片药有毒，另一片无毒。
options.en: One of them was poisonous, another one was harmless.

analysis: 文中描述Holmes在证实自己的猜想后，很激动地说“Of the two pills in that box, one was of the most deadly poison, and the other was entirely harmless. ” 说明药盒中的药，一片是有毒的，一片是无毒的，故选C项。
